DOC.HEAD: Former Black Panther Leader Gets Probation in Bad-Check Case
DOC.TEXT: Former Black Panther Bobby Seale has been put on probation for a year for writing bad checks in a financially disastrous venture to sell ribs at a barbecue festival. Seale, 52, also was fined $1,000 Tuesday and ordered to serve 100 hours of community service. He pleaded guilty Nov. 20 to four misdemeanor counts after being charged with passing bad checks for more than $10,700 in ribs, lodging and other expenses for his booth at Cleveland's National Rib Cook-Off in 1988. ``I had no intention whatsoever to defraud,'' he told Common Pleas Judge William Aurelius. ``I have a son in college ... I rent. I've been trying to take care of my family. I do all kinds of community service.'' Aurelius noted that Seale has paid off his approximately $11,000 debt, which Seale said resulted from poor sales and higher-than-expected expenses. Seale was co-founder of the radical Black Panthers in the 1960s and was arrested with the Chicago Seven for allegedly conspiring to incite the 1968 riots outside the Democratic National Convention in Chicago. Seale helps teach disadvantaged youngsters to rebuild abandoned houses in Philadelphia, where he is a community liaison for Temple University, his lawyer said.
